Key Match Events: South Africa have been denied a victory in their T20 World Cup opener after rain meant their reduced fixture against Zimbabwe could not be completed.

After a two-hour and 35-minute delay, the match was reduced to nine-overs a side. Zimbabwe recovered from being 19 for 4 to set South Africa a target of 80, which was then cut down to a target of 64 in seven overs.
Quinton de Kock blasted an 18-ball 47, with eight fours and a six.
Richard Ngarava slipped in his follow-through and had to leave the field due to injury.
Wayne Parnell and Lungi Ngidi took three wickets for 26 runs in four overs between them.
Zimbabwe's Powerplay resulted in only 14 runs for the loss of three wickets.
Pre-Game Insights: Craig Ervine decided to bat first after winning the toss, believing it was important to get runs on the board first.
South Africa went with a four-pronged pace pack and just one specialist spinner, with Keshav Maharaj keeping the spin berth.
Post-Match Reflections: The one point South Africa have dropped could be crucial in the context of the tournament. Assuming there are no major upsets in this group, their match against Pakistan on Thursday becomes a virtual quarterfinal.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Rain interrupted play multiple times, reducing the game to 20 overs per side.
South Africa have some history with rain-affected games, including their semi-final in 1992 and their first-round exit in 2003.
